Image.title: Image
Image.description: Represents an uploaded image and its associated data.

id.description: Unique identifier for the image entity.

userId.description: Reference to the User who uploaded the image. (Relationship: User 1:N Image)

storagePath.description: The path to the image in Firebase Storage.

directUrl.description: Direct URL for accessing the image.

htmlCode.description: HTML code representation of the image.

uploadTimestamp.description: Timestamp of when the image was uploaded.

originalName.description: The original name of the file when uploaded.

title.description: A user-provided or AI-generated title for the image.

description.description: A user-provided or AI-generated description of the image.

hashtags.description: A space-separated string of user-provided or AI-generated hashtags.

fileSize.description: Size of the uploaded file in bytes.

mimeType.description: MIME type of the uploaded image (e.g., image/jpeg, image/png).

likeCount.description: Number of likes the image has received.

generatedByAI.description: Flag indicating if the description was generated by AI, used for achievements.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the image uploading application.  Note: Authentication details (passwords, etc.) are handled by Firebase Auth and are NOT stored in this entity.

id.description: Unique identifier for the user entity.

creationTimestamp.description: Timestamp of when the user account was created.

ticketCount.description: Number of remaining daily upload tickets for the user.

lastTicketRefill.description: Timestamp of the last time the user's daily tickets were refilled.

aiTicketCount.description: Number of remaining daily AI generation tickets for the user.

lastAiTicketRefill.description: Timestamp of the last time the user's daily AI tickets were refilled.

aiTicketMonthlyCount.description: Tracks the total number of free AI tickets granted in the current monthly cycle.

aiTicketMonthlyReset.description: Timestamp of the last time the monthly AI ticket counter was reset.

emailNotifications.description: Indicates if the user has opted-in to receive email notifications.

bio.description: A short biography or description of the user.

websiteUrl.description: URL to the user's personal website.

level.description: The user's current level in the gamification system.

unlockedAchievements.description: A list of identifiers for the achievements the user has unlocked.

pinnedImageIds.description: A list of image IDs that the user has globally pinned or marked as favorites.

initialPhotoURL.description: The user's photoURL at the time of account creation.

profilePictureUpdateCount.description: Counts how many times the user has updated their profile picture.

Note.title: Note
Note.description: Represents a simple text note created by a user, which can be marked as completed.

userId.description: ID of the user who created the note.

completed.description: Whether the note/task has been completed.

createdAt.description: Timestamp of when the note was created.

Gallery.title: Gallery
Gallery.description: Represents a user-created gallery (album or collection) of images.

userId.description: ID of the user who owns the gallery.

description.description: An optional description for the gallery.

imageIds.description: An ordered list of ALL image IDs included in the gallery.

pinnedImageIds.description: A list of image IDs from this gallery that are 'pinned' or marked as favorites.

createdAt.description: Timestamp of when the gallery was created.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to provide a secure and scalable solution for the image uploading application, aligning with the core design principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters). 

To ensure Authorization Independence (Strategy A), the structure uses path-based ownership for images. Images are stored as subcollections of user documents (`/users/{userId}/images/{imageId}`), implicitly granting ownership to the user identified by `{userId}`. No denormalization is needed here, as path-based ownership inherently provides authorization context without requiring `get()` calls in the security rules.

Structural Segregation (Strategy B) is applied by storing all images belonging to a user in the same subcollection. This ensures a homogenous security posture, as all documents within `/users/{userId}/images` share the same security requirements (owned by the user).

Access Modeling (Strategy C) leverages path-based ownership, a standard and consistent pattern for private data. This simplifies security rules, making them more robust and easier to debug. Since no roles or membership maps are required, this eliminates potential complexities in managing authorization.

The design supports the required QAPs (Rules are not Filters) by using path-based ownership. Listing images is inherently scoped to a user's images, which can be secured using rules that only allow the user associated with the `/users/{userId}` path to list images under that path. This avoids the need to filter results based on user ID, ensuring efficient and secure list operations. It also allows a simple admin role to be implemented via a separate collection like `/roles_admin/{adminId}`.
